title: Do you ever write essays that you never intend to publish? - Quora

response.answer_text: Yes and no. I would never bother to write a formal essay that wasn’t for a specific purpose such as part of an educational requirement, a work requirement, or for publication. The yes part is about informal essays. I have been asked questions by friends that I just couldn’t answer in a messenger length text etc. Those pieces are essays in the sense that there is a structure, a point to their writing and a formulating and exploration of the subject. They often form a more ‘how to’ style. The style will be more colloquial and sarcastic than my Quora answers too. Exploring a subject by using an essay format often helps me form my own thoughts on a particular subject. I sometimes read my own answers from years ago to refresh my memory, as an example. When I am writing such pieces they are for my personal use. I also share them with some people to answer questions in publishing but those people are limited. Often because what I have written included private or secure information about finances. More often though I will pick a question on Quora and write an essay as an answer to explore the question and my thoughts. In a sense it is published but I don’t consider writing on Quora publishing so again a yes and no. As others have said writing pieces is more often to share ideas. It is one of the reasons why my Quora answers tend to run long. As a writer I have a lot of words sitting on my hard drive that aren’t published. For fiction that is sitting around 100k words at the very least, non fiction would include handwritten which is many times that. Sometimes it is about timing though and what today I think I will never publish might be the focus a year or more from now. Thanks for the A2A Sun Kim.

I have a lead-light bookcase in my study where the bottom shelf is reserved for my notebooks, about 30 X A4 X 180 pages. Most are my travel diaries - but others are subject-related or just plain ‘general’ notebooks. Taken together, I suppose these several thousand pages in my own handwriting serve as a rather unruly mind-map to my writing life. There are plenty of essays, or part essays, or essay beginnings, or essay ideas in there that I will never publish. I certainly don’t intend to. The writing of them has been the most important thing. Writing is the transfer of thoughts into a widely understood system of marks on paper. It takes practice. Clear thinking also takes practice. That’s why I find my notebooks so valuable. They continue to give me the room to flex my muscles without constraint. They have done more than that. They provide me with a record of my intellectual excitement in the early years and its sometimes downright foolish or foolhardy sparks, and they can also show the way this excitement is gradually tempered with time.

Yes! Many writers do. Personally, I think writing an essay—even just a short one—is a fun way to test my knowledge on something. It also allows the writer to become more familiar with constructing academic papers which, for many, are the most frustrating, or intricate, assignments. I do this with my creative writing as well.

“Essays” or an “essay” is a vague word. Now I’ve written many books and many short stories and all have been published, eventually. What would be the sense of writing anything unless it was meant to be read by someone? One need not be a recognized author to write and share with friends and family. Writing is and/or can be a great joy. So write! One of my recent books is a collection of short stories titled The Magi’s Gift of Gold and Twelve More Story Stories. Obtain a copy and see what you too can do.

All the time. Writing is therapy. Every piece I write is like flexing my muscles. Testing new concepts, ideas or expanding my thinking. Even if you’re good at writing, you still write to express your thoughts and grow your skill… or to maintain your skill. Even a pianist does not sit down at the piano for concerts only.  #Writing

Oh, definitely! Sometimes you want to write something down that helps you sort your thoughts or cope with pain and too much emotion. Those articles don’t have to be published if you don’t want them to (but from my experience they are the articles that have the most impact on your audience).

I tend to write every day, so now it’s my habit. And of course, sometimes I just write something that excites me with no intention to publicize it. It’s a good practice and a great opportunity to allow myself to cross all borders and try new styles.
All the time. It’s one of the best ways for one to clear up ideas→put them on paper and look at them.
